What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: a wondrous overview of the philosophy and politics behind language based on Stanley and Beaver's soon-to-be published book "The Politics of Language". I had a great time learning about (and helping to develop) their new framework of presupposition and more. I learned about how language has all these facets that I had never considered before and learned how to engage and discuss these topics which are so very relevant in an age of Russian politics and American politics that are so complicated and/or dastardly. Also got help on writing my first philosophy papers ever which was great !

Explored the relationship between language and power, and also explored what philosophy of language can look like when liberated from the work of Frege, Russell, and other philosophers in the analytic tradition.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof. Stanley is a very helpful great guy who always keeps class interesting. I enjoyed all of our discussions which have inspired much more further study in the field. I would say my only change would be to have a more set-in-stone plan for the syllabus and assignments, but I understood that we progressed based on what we needed to discuss, so I don't think that hurt us at all. It just leaves a little bit of uncertainty in the students' mind, but it did in fact work out just fine! This class is super relevant to the real world which I loved about it since it was very academic but also super relevant. Very accommodating to students of all academic disciplines.
Professor Stanley always managed to foster very lively class discussions, keeping students engaged, but sometimes it felt that course material could be a little better organized.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. If you are interested in the field of political language, philosophy of language or anything of the like, yessss. I had little phil of lang experience (meaning actually none except for an intro logic course and a racism course), and I had a wonderful experience in the class. Since we were discussing an entirely new framework (from the ground up) it wasn't too hard for me to hop right into the debate with everyone else. Really applicable and great stuff for the state of affairs in politics that we have. You also don't get dogged with useless assignments which is great too.
If you are down to engage in philosophical conversations  Yes.
Yes! If you get a chance to take this class and are interested in philosophy of language or Professor Stanley's work, take it!
